A dilemma unresolved, that every animal on earth seems to live by consuming others, (and legions of the smallest consume the largest).
Are the Jains futile in their effort to avoid killing anything while we live at the cost of sending countless microbes to doom?
We resist killing for food even as we kill for resources and territory and pollute the media of life, the water and air. Are we brought to Krishna's advice to have no compunctions?
Is the final arbiter merely utilitarian or also compassionate? A long life has led me to believe that it is the intangible, the emotional investment, that values life and sustains it.

I tell you, I feel it when my tire crushes some creature inadvertently. I feel it when my windshield splatters a Monarch Butterfly on its way to Mexico. How to resolve this mortal and moral dilemma?

And where does sentience begin and end, if it ends at all? Is it only our own limitations that fail to see a pervasive sense in every iota and biota?
Maybe the children will someday reveal where curiosity comes from.

Playoffs are universally a money grab, a way to artificially lengthen a season and to ramp up the "importance" of games.

Ironically, as you call for MLS to do away with the playoffs, they are actually growing in ubiquity in European football. England, in particular, has gone bonkers over the promotion playoffs, christening the Championship playoff final for the last promotion spot to the Premier League "The Thirty Million Pound Match." They get 75-90,000 to pack Wembley for the occasion. Germany puts its third from bottom team in a relegation playoff with the third from top in the 2.Bundesliga. And in Holland, not only are there relegation playoffs, but there are even playoffs for European spots. Mexico has been using playoffs for years, seemingly without complaint, even with the "superlider," or top points accumulator rarely winning the trophy.

Yes, the purist likes the straight table and a sraightforward crowning of a league champion. How's that going to work out, suspense-wise, in Spain, Germany and England, with all of those trophies all but done and dusted?

As for scheduling, of course MLS needs to get in line with the rest of the world, but more importantly, it needs to do away with a ridiculous playoff structure.

Yes, American sports fans like playoffs, but NBC didn't buy the Premiership TV rights for no reason: more American fans are watching, following, and loving the European game. These same fans are the ones going to the MLS matches here, and they will welcome a more traditional points/table structure. When these fans explain it to their friends, they'll take it as it is. Frankly, explaining the BCS ranking system and the equally crazy playoff scheme they've come up with in college football is a much greater task.

Also, to keep with the whole regionalism thing, why not make it even more so? Go to a single table for all teams, but have regional cups throughout the year, so a team who is out of MLS Cup or Open Cup contention has something else to keep supporters interested? The Cascadia Cup is a good start, but broaden it to the West Coast Cup and add a couple more fixtures...bring in some NASL teams... Keep it interesting!

Now if only the NASL and USL could run some sort of provisional promotion/relegation program for a few years, but I'm just rambling now...

ClearEye is less than clear-eyed about the effects of inflation on taxation and the budget deficit. Under Carter, inflation soared to over 10% per year, which increased all nominal magnitudes, including tax receipts. That is, inflation caused a huge tax increase.

The only reason the deficit would have come down in a second Carter term was because high inflation would have continued and so too would the high tax receipts.

One of the big reasons the deficit increased under Reagan is that he supported Paul Volcker in beating inflation down to 4%. This acted like a big tax cut for all Americans.

Democrats like Carter and ClearEye are all in favor of high inflation and high taxes, even though this slows long-run economic growth. Republicans are in the opposite camp.

I would rather see real efforts at rehabilitation. Punishment means taking away something of value. Society has deemed that since freedom is the one thing we all value, taking it away is punishment. Doing that is sufficient, in my opinion.

The act of execution, in my opinion, is not validated by the fact that a judge or a jury, has decided on it as punishment. To me, murder and execution are equivalently wrong. If it is wrong to kill, then there is no valid way of doing or sanctioning it.

So, in the case of Gilmore and withholding execution because he welcomes it, or stopping one, in the case of someone who shows remorse is is rehabilitated, are considerations without any value because killing by execution is fundamentally wrong.

If, when we punish, we are trying to exact revenge, then we are no different than the perpetrators. Punishment and revenge are not the same thing even though when crimes are particularly heinous, it can seem that life in prison is somehow insufficient. That doesn't mean we should make the punishment equally hurtful. Sentencing guidelines and the ethics behind them are not to design a punishment that is tailored to exact/inflict pain on the perpetrator on an individual basis, but rather weighs the penalty for each class of crime and recommend appropriate punishments for each.

See http://evans-experientialism.freewebspace.com/evans_retribution.htm for the ethics behind sentencing.

I use Trip Adviser to research all of our travel plans and I also have contributed a number of reviews over the years. I'm actually surprised that this article is much less positive about Trip Adviser than my experience would suggest. I love Trip Adviser and find it very helpful. (By way of disclosure, I work in health care and have absolutely no conflict of interest with Trip Adviser or other travel services.)

When I use Trip Adviser, I always look for consistent themes and more recent reviews. I tend to interpret the reviews that I read based on the price and apparent level of the establishment. If I'm looking for a 3 star hotel, I don't expect the same level of services and amenities that I'd expect at a 5 star hotel and I try to be clear about those distinctions in my reviews. I've stayed at and eaten at some of the top places in the world, but I typically eat and stay at much more modest establishments. I rate them according to the their level of excellence within their relative level/cost and I make sure to comment on value, location and other facets.

I also check the Trip Adviser suggestions with other guidebooks and web sites before making final plans. Overall, we have been extremely pleased with the places that we've chosen using Trip Adviser.

I should also note that there have been a few times (about 3% of my reviews) in which our experience has been quite negative. I've posted what I feel to be a balanced review and have never had it questioned.

This suggest a dramatic, swift easy way to wake up giants and improve public health: let's halve our soda consumption (I was about to suggest a 90% reduction, but I'm following Marc's lead and being patient).

How many minutes of commercials for soda do we see for each minute of commercials that warn about the dangers of sugary drinks? The taste for sugar is partially acquired, and even if it is partially part of our makeup, a distaste for sugar can be learned.

Advertising for weight loss programs and products implicitly encourages people to eat less or healthier, and somewhat counters the advertisements for what has come to be our ordinary commercial diet. Advertising for sugar-free drinks can counter the ads for sugared sodas, but there is not much advertising for bottled water and none for tap water.

In addition, advertising for health is in a different category and tends to be seen differently, as coming from nanny-staters or do-gooders. It is a telling measure of our commercial society mindset that ads that try to sell us something are seen as more legitimate than ads that try to help us.
